content:
This standard describes requirements for flexible foam used in JYSK products.

| Section   | Changes                                               |
|:----------|:------------------------------------------------------|
| Iba       | Indentation factor requirements moved to chapter 3.3. |

| nan | HArdneSS ..... cece ccceeeeeeeeeeeeeees                                                                                                      |
| 3.1 | Indentation hardness ...........                                                                                                             |
| 3.2 | Compression hardness .........                                                                                                               |
| 3.3 | Indentation factor................                                                                                                           |
| nan | Compression Set (Dry CONItIONS) ........ cece cece eee cece eee e eee eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeteeeeeeegs |
| WI  | Dynamic fatigue ...............85.                                                                                                           |
| OD  | Tensile strength and elongation at Dreak ....... cece cece cece cece eee cece eee eeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeeueeceeeneceteueeeeseeeeesegeggs    |
| N   | Determination of ash............                                                                                                             |
| Oo  | Additional foam specifications                                                                                                               |

The nominal resilience of foam must be specified according to ISO 8307.

If resilience is not specified by the supplier JYSK will assume the resilience according to Table 1. The specified/assumed nominal resilience is used to determine several other requirements. Resilience is an indicator of the surface elasticity and springiness. Testing is performed by dropping a steel ball onto the foam sample from a specified drop height and measuring rebound. The resilience is expressed as the rebound height in percent of the initial drop height.

| Low     |   Unnamed: 1 |   Conventional |   Unnamed: 3 | Unnamed: 4   |   High | Unnamed: 6   |   Unnamed: 7 |
|:--------|-------------:|---------------:|-------------:|:-------------|-------:|:-------------|-------------:|
| +—_+ 15 |           20 |            nan |           45 | +—t 50       |     70 | +—+ 75       |          100 |

| ('Unnamed: 0_level_0', 'Low-resilient', 'e Memory foam', '¢ Viscoelastic foam')   | ('Polyurethane', 'Conventional', 'e Standard polyether', 'Unnamed: 1_level_3')   | ('Unnamed: 2_level_0', 'High-resilient', 'e Cold foam', 'Unnamed: 2_level_3')

The nominal density of foam must be specified in kilograms per cubic metre [kg/m3] according to ISO 845 using “standard atmosphere – a”.

Density is mass per volume and can be defined by the following formula:

𝜌 is the density

𝑚 is the mass

𝑉 is the volume

The density measured on foam is technically an ‘apparent density’ as foams are inherently not solid materials. ‘Apparent density’ means cellular mass per unit volume of a sample such as a foam block. An approximated test based on similar principles is simple to recreate using a suitable weighing scale.

Specified foam densities must comply with the minimum densities stated in Table 2.

|   Low-resilient |   Conventional |   High-resilient |
|----------------:|---------------:|-----------------:|
|             230 |            218 |              223 |

Delivered foam must comply with the specified nominal density ±10% unless otherwise agreed upon with CAM and JYSK C&Q.

The nominal hardness of foam must be specified as indentation hardness according to 3.1 and/or compression hardness according to 3.2.

Hardness indicates the load-bearing properties of a foam and how it will feel for the end user. Indentation hardness and compression hardness are not to be directly converted!

Delivered foam must comply with applicable requirements in Table 3 and 3.3 unless otherwise agreed upon with CAM and JYSK C&Q.

| General foam requirement    | +20%   |
|:----------------------------|:-------|
| Foam in mattresses and beds | +£15%  |

Indentation hardness must be specified in Newton [N] according to ISO 2439 - Method B (40% indentation / 30 second hold period).

Indentation hardness is a measure of the load bearing properties of a foam when pressure is applied on an area smaller than the full sample surface.

Other common names for indentation hardness are:

• Indentation Force Deflection (IFD)

• Indentation Load Deflection (ILD)

Page 4/9

Compression hardness must be specified using the compression stress value (CV40) measured in kilopascal [kPa] according to ISO 3386-1.

Compression hardness is a measure of the load bearing properties of a foam when pressure is applied on the complete area of the sample.

Other common names for compression hardness are:

• Compression Load Deflection (CLD)

• Compression Force Deflection (CFD)

1 𝑘𝑃𝑎 = 1000 𝑚𝑚2

Page 5/9

Delivered foam must comply with applicable requirements in Table 4 when tested according to ISO 2439 – Method B.

The indentation factor is an indicator of how a foam “cushions” and “supports”.

𝐻𝐵(65%/30𝑠) is the hardness recorded at 65% indentation and 30 second hold period

𝐻𝐵(25%/30𝑠) is the hardness recorded at 25% indentation and 30 second hold period

Other common names for indentation factor are:

• Support factor

• Compression modulus

• Deflection factor

|   ('Unnamed: 0_level_0', 'Low-resilient') |   ('Polyurethane', 'Conventional') |   ('Unnamed: 2_level_0', 'High-resilient') |   ('Latex', 'Latex') |
|------------------------------------------:|-----------------------------------:|-------------------------------------------:|---------------------:|
|                                       nan |                                218 |                                        222 |                  224 |

Page 6/9

Delivered foam must comply with applicable requirements in Table 6 and Table 7 when tested according to ISO 1856 - Method A using the configuration stated in Table 5.

Compression set is the difference between initial and final thickness of a foam sample after compressed storage in a clamping device under certain conditions.

Definition: 𝐶𝑜𝑚𝑝𝑟𝑒𝑠𝑠𝑖𝑜𝑛 𝑠𝑒𝑡 =

𝑑𝑜 is the initial thickness of the sample in millimetres [mm]

𝑑𝑟 is the thickness of the foam sample after recovery in millimetres [mm]

JYSK uses compression set as an indicator of a foam’s ability to withstand compressive forces applied during daily use. Requirements apply in the compression direction of the foam in the actual product.

| Time        | 22 hours   |
|:------------|:-----------|
| Temperature | 70°C       |
| Compression | 50%        |

| ('Density (D) - (See 2)', 'Density (D) - (See 2)')   | ('Resilience (R) - (See 1)', 'R>20')   |   ('Resilience (R) - (See 1)', 'Unnamed: 2_level_1') | ('Resilience (R) - (See 1)', '

Delivered foam must comply with the requirements stated in Table 8 and Table 9 when tested according to ISO 3385.

Dynamic fatigue is the ability of a foam to withstand dynamic loads.

Foams with a resilience ≤20 are not subject to dynamic fatigue requirements as slow rebound conflicts with the test method.

| ('Density (D) - (see 2)', 'Density (D) - (see 2)')   | ('Resilience (R) - (see 1)', 'R245')   | ('Resilience (R) - (see 1)', '45>R>20')   |   ('Resilience (R) - (see 1)', 'Rs<20') |

Delivered foam must comply with the requirements stated in Table 10 when tested according to ISO 1798 using test piece – Type 1.

Tensile strength and elongation at break are two parameters used to describe the tensile characteristics of foam. Tensile characteristics are mainly used as indicators of other related qualities and properties of the foam.

Tensile strength (TS) is measured in kilopascal [kPa] (1 𝑘𝑃𝑎 = 1000

Elongation at break (Eb) is measured in % of original gauge length (𝐸𝑏 =

| Minimum elongation at break (Ep) | 280%                                                                           | 280%                                                                           | 280%                                                                           | 280%                     |

Delivered foam must show a mass of ash residue after incineration in accordance with Table 11 when tested according to ISO 3451-1 - method A using a calcining temperature of 700±25°C.

| 0          | 1   |
|:-----------|:----|
| Latex foam | <8% |

Edition 2 – 2023-12 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
This standard describes requirements for flexible foam used in JYSK products.

Section Changes General revision: • New standard format. All • Updated wording (Substance and requirements remain the same). • Updated tables and references. • Descriptive texts stated as notes. Significant changes in wording is highlighted in red. 3 Indentation factor requirements moved to chapter 3.3. 6 Updated requirements on tensile strength and elongation at break.
Edition 2 – 2023-12 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
The nominal resilience of foam must be specified according to ISO 8307.

If resilience is not specified by the supplier JYSK will assume the resilience according to Table 1. The specified/assumed nominal resilience is used to determine several other requirements. Resilience is an indicator of the surface elasticity and springiness. Testing is performed by dropping a steel ball onto the foam sample from a specified drop height and measuring rebound. The resilience is expressed as the rebound height in percent of the initial drop height.

The nominal density of foam must be specified in kilograms per cubic metre [kg/m3] according to ISO 845 using “standard atmosphere – a”.
Density is mass per volume and can be defined by the following formula:
𝜌 is the density
𝑚 is the mass
𝑉 is the volume

The density measured on foam is technically an ‘apparent density’ as foams are inherently not solid materials. ‘Apparent density’ means cellular mass per unit volume of a sample such as a foam block. An approximated test based on similar principles is simple to recreate using a suitable weighing scale.
Specified foam densities must comply with the minimum densities stated in Table 2.

4 Compression set (Dry conditions)
Delivered foam must comply with applicable requirements in Table 6 and Table 7 when tested according to ISO 1856 - Method A using the configuration stated in Table 5.
Compression set is the difference between initial and final thickness of a foam sample after compressed storage in a clamping device under certain conditions.

𝑑𝑟 is the thickness of the foam sample after recovery in millimetres [mm]

JYSK uses compression set as an indicator of a foam’s ability to withstand compressive forces applied during daily use. Requirements apply in the compression direction of the foam in the actual product.

6 Tensile strength and elongation at break
Delivered foam must comply with the requirements stated in Table 10 when tested according to ISO 1798 using test piece – Type 1.

Tensile strength and elongation at break are two parameters used to describe the tensile characteristics of foam. Tensile characteristics are mainly used as indicators of other related qualities and properties of the foam.
Tensile strength (TS) is measured in kilopascal [kPa] (1 𝑘𝑃𝑎 = 1000
Elongation at break (Eb) is measured in % of original gauge length (𝐸𝑏 =

Minimum elongation ≥80% at break (Eb)
Table 10 – Requirements for tensile strength and elongation
7 Determination of ash
Delivered foam must show a mass of ash residue after incineration in accordance with Table 11 when tested according to ISO 3451-1 - method A using a calcining temperature of 700±25°C.
Polyurethane foam ≤5% Latex foam ≤8%
Table 11 – Maximum residue after incineration
Edition 2 – 2023-12 Compliancequality@JYSK.com
8 Additional foam specifications
Additional foam specifications can be agreed upon according to Table 12.
